The proposed approach enables improved regional solar PV estimation and forecasting, either on its own or in conjunction with additional data sources, such as satellite imagery, within a deep learning framework. This method has the potential to further enable significant uptake of solar PV, assisting a shift away from fossil fuel-based generation.

Introduction

Global installation of solar photovoltaic (PV) generation continues to accelerate, and solar PV is now the fastest-growing form of electricity generation worldwide. However, high levels of solar PV can lead to complex issues for existing electrical grids. For instance, Western Australia, which has one of the highest rates of solar uptake in the world, is experiencing problems due to distributed rooftop solar PV. The national energy market operator has reported extensively on the issues caused by this distributed solar PV, including:

- Grid instability: Many distribution feeders are now feeding back into the grid for extended periods, leading to problems with voltage control and frequency stability.
- System volatility: Significant fluctuations in generation occur when cloud bands pass over neighborhoods with high levels of solar PV, which must be handled by short-term reserves and ancillary services.
- New contingency risks: During disturbances, inverters may trip for short periods, which can be equivalent to a major generator temporarily going offline.
- System restart: After blackouts, a certain level of load is required to re-energize the system, and this can be difficult to achieve when many neighborhoods are behaving like generators.
- Market volatility: High levels of distributed solar PV can be difficult for market operators to forecast, making markets more volatile.

These issues are already starting to have a major impact on system and market operation in Australia and other markets with high uptake. Given the rates of uptake across many other geographies, it is likely that these problems will emerge in many parts of the world in the coming 5-10 years. If not addressed, there is a risk that uptake of solar PV will be slowed, generation levels of existing systems may be curtailed, and the full potential for reducing greenhouse gas emissions may not be realized.

Fortunately, many of these issues can be addressed by emerging technologies and tools, such as energy storage and improved solar PV estimation and forecasting. There has been extensive work on forecasting solar output of individual systems, using various approaches, including numerical weather prediction, on-site sky imaging systems, satellite imagery, statistical forecasting tools, and machine learning to develop probabilistic forecasts.

However, what is urgently required now is a better ability to forecast distributed solar PV generation for entire regions, such as a whole distribution feeder or an entire market zone. To date, this has been difficult to do due to the lack of direct access to metering and sensing of all distributed solar PV systems, as well as the actual number and generating capacities of all systems, which may not even be known. An ability to estimate and forecast solar PV generation across entire regions is becoming increasingly essential, as it would allow system operators to better handle and plan for the issues introduced by distributed solar PV.

In this paper, we present a proposal for a new approach to estimation and forecasting of solar PV generation across entire regions. We describe a method for generating solar PV "maps" for large regions using a small set of metered data.
